title: Visual impairment
text:
Visual impairment, also known as vision impairment or vision loss, is a decreased ability to <a href="visual%20perception">see</a> to a degree that causes problems not fixable by usual means, such as <a href="glasses">glasses</a>. Some also include those who have a decreased ability to see because they do not have access to glasses or <a href="contact%20lens">contact lens</a>es. Visual impairment is often defined as a best corrected <a href="visual%20acuity">visual acuity</a> of worse than either 20/40 or 20/60. The term blindness is used for complete or nearly complete vision loss. Visual impairment may cause difficulties with normal daily activities such as reading and walking without adaptive training and equipment.
The most common causes of visual impairment globally are uncorrected <a href="refractive%20errors">refractive errors</a> (43%), <a href="cataract">cataract</a>s (33%), and <a href="glaucoma">glaucoma</a> (2%). Refractive errors include <a href="near-sightedness">near-sightedness</a>, <a href="far-sightedness">far-sightedness</a>, <a href="presbyopia">presbyopia</a>, and <a href="astigmatism%20%28eye%29">astigmatism</a>. Cataracts are the most common cause of blindness. Other disorders that may cause visual problems include <a href="age-related%20macular%20degeneration">age-related macular degeneration</a>, <a href="diabetic%20retinopathy">diabetic retinopathy</a>, <a href="corneal%20opacification">corneal clouding</a>, <a href="childhood%20blindness">childhood blindness</a>, and a number of <a href="infection">infection</a>s. Visual impairment can also be caused by problems in the <a href="brain">brain</a> due to <a href="stroke">stroke</a>, <a href="premature%20birth">premature birth</a>, or trauma, among others. These cases are known as <a href="cortical%20visual%20impairment">cortical visual impairment</a>. Screening for vision problems in children may improve future vision and educational achievement. Screening adults without symptoms is of uncertain benefit. Diagnosis is by an <a href="eye%20exam">eye exam</a>.
The <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) estimates that 80% of visual impairment is either preventable or curable with treatment. This includes cataracts, the infections <a href="onchocerciasis">river blindness</a> and <a href="trachoma">trachoma</a>, glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, uncorrected refractive errors, and some cases of childhood blindness. Many people with significant visual impairment benefit from <a href="vision%20rehabilitation">vision rehabilitation</a>, changes in their environment, and assistive devices.
As of 2015 there were 940 million people with some degree of vision loss. 246 million had low vision and 39 million were blind. The majority of people with poor vision are in the <a href="developing%20world">developing world</a> and are over the age of 50 years. Rates of visual impairment have decreased since the 1990s. Visual impairments have considerable economic costs both directly due to the cost of treatment and indirectly due to decreased ability to work.
Classification.
The definition of visual impairment is reduced vision not corrected by <a href="glasses">glasses</a> or <a href="contact%20lens">contact lens</a>es. The World Health Organization uses the following classifications of visual impairment. When the vision in the better eye with best possible glasses correction is:
Blindness is defined by the <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">World Health Organization</a> as vision in a person's best eye with best correction of less than 20/500 or a <a href="visual%20field">visual field</a> of less than 10 degrees. This definition was set in 1972, and there is ongoing discussion as to whether it should be altered to officially include uncorrected refractive errors.
United Kingdom.
Severely sight impaired 
Sight impaired 
Low vision 
In the UK, the Certificate of Vision Impairment (CVI) is used to certify patients as severely sight impaired or sight impaired. The accompanying guidance for clinical staff states: "The National Assistance Act 1948 states that a person can be certified as severely sight impaired if they are 'so blind as to be unable to perform any work for which eye sight is essential'". Certification is based on whether a person can do any work for which eyesight is essential, not just one particular job (such as their job before becoming blind).
In practice, the definition depends on individuals' <a href="visual%20acuity">visual acuity</a> and the extent to which their <a href="field%20of%20vision">field of vision</a> is restricted. The <a href="Department%20of%20Health">Department of Health</a> identifies three groups of people who may be classified as severely visually impaired.
The Department of Health also state that a person is more likely to be classified as severely visually impaired if their eyesight has failed recently or if they are an older individual, both groups being perceived as less able to adapt to their vision loss.
United States.
In the United States, any person with vision that cannot be corrected to better than 20/200 in the best eye, or who has 20 <a href="visual%20angle">degrees</a> (<a href="angular%20diameter">diameter</a>) or less of visual field remaining, is considered legally blind or eligible for disability classification and possible inclusion in certain government sponsored programs.
In the United States, the terms "partially sighted", "low vision", "legally blind" and "totally blind" are used by schools, colleges, and other educational institutions to describe students with visual impairments. They are defined as follows:
In 1934, the <a href="American%20Medical%20Association">American Medical Association</a> adopted the following definition of blindness:
Central visual acuity of 20/200 or less in the better eye with corrective glasses or central visual acuity of more than 20/200 if there is a visual field defect in which the peripheral field is contracted to such an extent that the widest diameter of the visual field subtends an angular distance no greater than 20 degrees in the better eye.
The <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a> included this definition as part of the Aid to the Blind program in the passed in 1935. In 1972, the Aid to the Blind program and two others combined under Title XVI of the Social Security Act to form the <a href="Supplemental%20Security%20Income">Supplemental Security Income</a> program which states:
An individual shall be considered to be blind for purposes of this title if he has central visual acuity of 20/200 or less in the better eye with the use of a correcting lens. An eye which is accompanied by a limitation in the fields of vision such that the widest diameter of the visual field subtends an angle no greater than 20 degrees shall be considered for purposes of the first sentence of this subsection as having a central visual acuity of 20/200 or less. An individual shall also be considered to be blind for purposes of this title if he is blind as defined under a State plan approved under title X or XVI as in effect for October 1972 and received aid under such plan (on the basis of blindness) for December 1973, so long as he is continuously blind as so defined.
Health effects.
Visual impairments may take many forms and be of varying degrees. Visual acuity alone is not always a good predictor of the degree of problems a person may have. Someone with relatively good acuity (e.g., 20/40) can have difficulty with daily functioning, while someone with worse acuity (e.g., 20/200) may function reasonably well if their visual demands are not great.
The <a href="American%20Medical%20Association">American Medical Association</a> has estimated that the loss of one eye equals 25% impairment of the visual system and 24% impairment of the whole person; total loss of vision in both eyes is considered to be 100% visual impairment and 85% impairment of the whole person.
Some people who fall into this category can use their considerable residual vision – their remaining sight – to complete daily tasks without relying on alternative methods. The role of a low vision specialist (optometrist or ophthalmologist) is to maximize the functional level of a patient's vision by optical or non-optical means. Primarily, this is by use of magnification in the form of telescopic systems for distance vision and optical or electronic magnification for near tasks.
People with significantly reduced acuity may benefit from training conducted by individuals trained in the provision of technical aids. Low <a href="Vision%20Rehabilitation">vision rehabilitation</a> professionals, some of whom are connected to an agency for the blind, can provide advice on lighting and contrast to maximize remaining vision. These professionals also have access to non-visual aids, and can instruct patients in their uses.
The subjects making the most use of rehabilitation instruments, who lived alone, and preserved their own mobility and occupation were the least depressed, with the lowest risk of suicide and the highest level of social integration.
Those with worsening sight and the prognosis of eventual blindness are at comparatively high risk of suicide and thus may be in need of supportive services. Many studies have demonstrated how rapid acceptance of the serious visual handicap has led to a better, more productive compliance with rehabilitation programs. Moreover, psychological distress has been reported to be at its highest when sight loss is not complete, but the prognosis is unfavorable. Therefore, early intervention is imperative for enabling successful psychological adjustment.
Associated conditions.
Blindness can occur in combination with such conditions as <a href="intellectual%20disability">intellectual disability</a>, <a href="autism%20spectrum%20disorders">autism spectrum disorders</a>, <a href="cerebral%20palsy">cerebral palsy</a>, <a href="hearing%20impairment">hearing impairment</a>s, and <a href="epilepsy">epilepsy</a>. Blindness in combination with hearing loss is known as <a href="deafblindness">deafblindness</a>.
It has been estimated that over half of completely blind people have <a href="non-24-hour%20sleep%E2%80%93wake%20disorder">non-24-hour sleep–wake disorder</a>, a condition in which a person's <a href="circadian%20rhythm">circadian rhythm</a>, normally slightly longer than 24 hours, is not <a href="Entrainment%20%28chronobiology%29">entrained</a> (synchronized) to the lightdark cycle.

About 90% of people who are visually impaired live in the <a href="developing%20world">developing world</a>. Age-related macular degeneration, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy are the leading causes of blindness in the developed world.
Among working-age adults who are newly blind in England and Wales the most common causes in 2010 were:
Cataracts.
<a href="Cataracts">Cataracts</a> are the congenital and pediatric pathology that describes the greying or opacity of the crystalline lens, which is most commonly caused by intrauterine infections, metabolic disorders, and genetically transmitted syndromes. Cataracts are the leading cause of child and adult blindness that doubles in prevalence with every ten years after the age of 40. Consequently, today cataracts are more common among adults than in children. That is, people face higher chances of developing cataracts as they age. Nonetheless, cataracts tend to have a greater financial and emotional toll upon children as they must undergo expensive diagnosis, long term rehabilitation, and visual assistance. Also, according to the Saudi Journal for Health Sciences, sometimes patients experience irreversible amblyopia after pediatric cataract surgery because the cataracts prevented the normal maturation of vision prior to operation. Despite the great progress in treatment, cataracts remain a global problem in both economically developed and developing countries. At present, with the variant outcomes as well as the unequal access to cataract surgery, the best way to reduce the risk of developing cataracts is to avoid smoking and extensive exposure to sun light (i.e. UV-B rays).
Glaucoma.
<a href="Glaucoma">Glaucoma</a> is a congenital and pediatric eye disease characterized by increased pressure within the eye or intraocular pressure (IOP). Glaucoma causes visual field loss as well as severs the optic nerve. Early diagnosis and treatment of glaucoma in patients is imperative because glaucoma is triggered by non-specific levels of IOP. Also, another challenge in accurately diagnosing glaucoma is that the disease has four causes: 1) inflammatory ocular hypertension syndrome (IOHS); 2) severe uveitic angle closure; 3) corticosteroid-induced; and 4) a heterogonous mechanism associated with structural change and chronic inflammation. In addition, often <a href="pediatric%20glaucoma">pediatric glaucoma</a> differs greatly in cause and management from the glaucoma developed by adults. Currently, the best sign of pediatric glaucoma is an IOP of 21 mm Hg or greater present within a child. One of the most common causes of pediatric glaucoma is cataract removal surgery, which leads to an incidence rate of about 12.2% among infants and 58.7% among 10-year-olds.
Infections.
Childhood blindness can be caused by conditions related to pregnancy, such as <a href="congenital%20rubella%20syndrome">congenital rubella syndrome</a> and <a href="retinopathy%20of%20prematurity">retinopathy of prematurity</a>. Leprosy and onchocerciasis each blind approximately 1 million individuals in the developing world.
The number of individuals blind from <a href="trachoma">trachoma</a> has decreased in the past 10 years from 6 million to 1.3 million, putting it in seventh place on the list of causes of blindness worldwide.
Central corneal ulceration is also a significant cause of monocular blindness worldwide, accounting for an estimated 850,000 cases of corneal blindness every year in the Indian subcontinent alone. As a result, corneal scarring from all causes is now the fourth greatest cause of global blindness.
Injuries.
<a href="Eye%20injury">Eye injuries</a>, most often occurring in people under 30, are the leading cause of monocular blindness (vision loss in one eye) throughout the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. Injuries and cataracts affect the eye itself, while abnormalities such as <a href="optic%20nerve%20hypoplasia">optic nerve hypoplasia</a> affect the nerve bundle that sends signals from the eye to the back of the brain, which can lead to decreased visual acuity.
<a href="Cortical%20blindness">Cortical blindness</a> results from injuries to the <a href="occipital%20lobe">occipital lobe</a> of the <a href="Human%20brain">brain</a> that prevent the brain from correctly receiving or interpreting signals from the <a href="optic%20nerve">optic nerve</a>. Symptoms of cortical blindness vary greatly across individuals and may be more severe in periods of exhaustion or stress. It is common for people with cortical blindness to have poorer vision later in the day.
Blinding has been used as an <a href="blinding%20%28punishment%29">act of vengeance and torture</a> in some instances, to deprive a person of a major sense by which they can navigate or interact within the world, act fully independently, and be aware of events surrounding them. An example from the classical realm is <a href="Oedipus">Oedipus</a>, who gouges out his own eyes after realizing that he fulfilled the awful prophecy spoken of him. Having crushed the Bulgarians, the Byzantine Emperor <a href="Basil%20II">Basil II</a> blinded as many as 15,000 prisoners taken in the battle, before releasing them. Contemporary examples include the addition of methods such as <a href="acid%20throwing">acid throwing</a> as a form of <a href="disfigurement">disfigurement</a>.
Genetic defects.
People with <a href="albinism">albinism</a> often have vision loss to the extent that many are legally blind, though few of them actually cannot see. <a href="Leber%20congenital%20amaurosis">Leber congenital amaurosis</a> can cause total blindness or severe sight loss from birth or early childhood.
Recent advances in <a href="genetic%20map">mapping</a> of the <a href="human%20genome">human genome</a> have identified other genetic causes of <a href="low%20vision">low vision</a> or blindness. One such example is <a href="Bardet%E2%80%93Biedl%20syndrome">Bardet–Biedl syndrome</a>.
Poisoning.
Rarely, blindness is caused by the intake of certain chemicals. A well-known example is <a href="methanol">methanol</a>, which is only mildly toxic and minimally intoxicating, and breaks down into the substances <a href="formaldehyde">formaldehyde</a> and <a href="formic%20acid">formic acid</a> which in turn can cause blindness, an array of other health complications, and death. When competing with <a href="ethanol">ethanol</a> for metabolism, ethanol is metabolized first, and the onset of toxicity is delayed. Methanol is commonly found in <a href="methylated%20spirits">methylated spirits</a>, <a href="Denatured%20alcohol">denatured ethyl alcohol</a>, to avoid paying taxes on selling ethanol intended for human consumption. Methylated spirits are sometimes used by <a href="Alcoholism">alcoholics</a> as a <a href="surrogate%20alcohol">desperate and cheap substitute</a> for regular ethanol <a href="alcoholic%20beverages">alcoholic beverages</a>.
Diagnosis.
It is important that people be examined by someone specializing in low vision care prior to other rehabilitation training to rule out potential medical or surgical correction for the problem and to establish a careful baseline refraction and prescription of both normal and low vision glasses and optical aids. Only a doctor is qualified to evaluate visual functioning of a compromised visual system effectively. The <a href="American%20Medical%20Association">American Medical Association</a> provides an approach to evaluating visual loss as it affects an individual's ability to perform activities of daily living.
Screening adults who have no symptoms is of uncertain benefit.
Prevention.
The World Health Organization estimates that 80% of visual loss is either preventable or curable with treatment. This includes cataracts, onchocerciasis, trachoma, glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, uncorrected refractive errors, and some cases of childhood blindness. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that half of blindness in the United States is preventable.
Management.
Mobility.
Many people with serious visual impairments can travel independently, using a wide range of tools and techniques. <a href="Orientation%20and%20Mobility">Orientation and mobility specialists</a> are professionals who are specifically trained to teach people with visual impairments how to travel safely, confidently, and independently in the home and the community. These professionals can also help blind people to practice travelling on specific routes which they may use often, such as the route from one's house to a convenience store. Becoming familiar with an environment or route can make it much easier for a blind person to navigate successfully.
Tools such as the <a href="white%20cane">white cane</a> with a red tip – the <a href="international%20symbols">international symbol</a> of blindness – may also be used to improve mobility. A long cane is used to extend the user's range of touch sensation. It is usually swung in a low sweeping motion, across the intended path of travel, to detect obstacles. However, techniques for cane travel can vary depending on the user and/or the situation. Some visually impaired persons do not carry these kinds of canes, opting instead for the shorter, lighter identification (ID) cane. Still others require a support cane. The choice depends on the individual's vision, motivation, and other factors.
A small number of people employ <a href="guide%20dog">guide dog</a>s to assist in mobility. These dogs are trained to navigate around various obstacles, and to indicate when it becomes necessary to go up or down a step. However, the helpfulness of guide dogs is limited by the inability of dogs to understand complex directions. The human half of the guide dog team does the directing, based upon skills acquired through previous mobility training. In this sense, the handler might be likened to an aircraft's navigator, who must know how to get from one place to another, and the dog to the pilot, who gets them there safely.
<a href="GPS%20for%20the%20visually%20impaired">GPS devices</a> can also be used as a mobility aid. Such software can assist blind people with orientation and navigation, but it is not a replacement for traditional mobility tools such as white canes and guide dogs.
Some blind people are skilled at <a href="human%20echolocation">echolocating</a> silent objects simply by producing mouth clicks and listening to the returning echoes. It has been shown that blind echolocation experts use what is normally the "visual" part of their brain to process the echoes.
Government actions are sometimes taken to make public places more accessible to blind people. Public transportation is freely available to the blind in many cities. <a href="Tactile%20paving">Tactile paving</a> and <a href="Pedestrian%20crossing%23Enhancements%20for%20disabled%20people">audible traffic signals</a> can make it easier and safer for visually impaired pedestrians to cross streets. In addition to making rules about who can and cannot use a cane, some governments mandate the <a href="Priority%20%28right%20of%20way%29">right-of-way</a> be given to users of white canes or guide dogs.
Reading and magnification.
Most visually impaired people who are not totally blind read print, either of a regular size or enlarged by magnification devices. Many also read <a href="large-print">large-print</a>, which is easier for them to read without such devices. A variety of <a href="magnifying%20glass">magnifying glass</a>es, some handheld, and some on desktops, can make reading easier for them.
Others read <a href="braille">braille</a> (or the infrequently used <a href="Moon%20type">Moon type</a>), or rely on <a href="audiobook">talking books</a> and readers or <a href="reading%20machine">reading machine</a>s, which convert printed text to speech or <a href="braille">braille</a>. They use computers with special hardware such as <a href="image%20scanner">scanners</a> and <a href="refreshable%20Braille%20display">refreshable braille display</a>s as well as software written specifically for the blind, such as <a href="optical%20character%20recognition">optical character recognition</a> applications and <a href="screen%20reader">screen reader</a>s.
Some people access these materials through agencies for the blind, such as the <a href="National%20Library%20Service%20for%20the%20Blind%20and%20Physically%20Handicapped">National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped</a> in the United States, the <a href="National%20Library%20for%20the%20Blind">National Library for the Blind</a> or the <a href="Royal%20National%20Institute%20for%20the%20Blind">RNIB</a> in the United Kingdom.
<a href="Closed-circuit%20television">Closed-circuit television</a>s, equipment that enlarges and contrasts textual items, are a more <a href="high-tech">high-tech</a> alternative to traditional magnification devices.
There are also over 100 <a href="radio%20reading%20service">radio reading service</a>s throughout the world that provide people with vision impairments with readings from periodicals over the radio. The International Association of Audio Information Services provides links to all of these organizations.
Computers and mobile technology.
Access technology such as <a href="screen%20reader">screen reader</a>s, <a href="screen%20magnifier">screen magnifier</a>s and <a href="refreshable%20Braille%20display">refreshable braille display</a>s enable the blind to use mainstream computer applications and <a href="mobile%20phone">mobile phone</a>s. The availability of assistive technology is increasing, accompanied by concerted efforts to ensure the accessibility of information technology to all potential users, including the blind. Later versions of <a href="Microsoft%20Windows">Microsoft Windows</a> include an Accessibility Wizard & Magnifier for those with partial vision, and <a href="Microsoft%20Narrator">Microsoft Narrator</a>, a simple screen reader. <a href="Linux%20distribution">Linux distribution</a>s (as <a href="live%20CD">live CD</a>s) for the blind include <a href="Vinux">Vinux</a> and <a href="Adriane%20Knoppix">Adriane Knoppix</a>, the latter developed in part by <a href="Klaus%20Knopper">Adriane Knopper</a> who has a visual impairment. macOS and iOS also come with a built-in screen reader called <a href="VoiceOver">VoiceOver</a>, while <a href="Google%20TalkBack">Google TalkBack</a> is built in to most Android devices.
The movement towards greater <a href="web%20accessibility">web accessibility</a> is opening a far wider number of websites to <a href="adaptive%20technology">adaptive technology</a>, making the web a more inviting place for visually impaired surfers.
Experimental approaches in <a href="sensory%20substitution">sensory substitution</a> are beginning to provide access to arbitrary live views from a <a href="camera">camera</a>.
Modified visual output that includes large print and/or clear simple graphics can be of benefit to users with some residual vision.
Other aids and techniques.
Blind people may use talking equipment such as <a href="thermometer">thermometer</a>s, watches, clocks, <a href="weighing%20scale">scales</a>, <a href="calculator">calculator</a>s, and <a href="compass">compass</a>es. They may also enlarge or mark dials on devices such as ovens and thermostats to make them usable. Other techniques used by blind people to assist them in daily activities include:
Most people, once they have been visually impaired for long enough, devise their own adaptive strategies in all areas of personal and professional management.
For the blind, there are books in braille, audio-books, and text-to-speech computer programs, machines and <a href="e-book%20readers">e-book readers</a>. Low vision people can make use of these tools as well as <a href="large-print">large-print</a> reading materials and e-book readers that provide large <a href="font">font</a> sizes.
Computers are important tools of integration for the visually impaired person. They allow, using standard or specific programs, screen magnification and conversion of text into sound or touch (braille line), and are useful for all levels of visual handicap. <a href="Optical%20character%20recognition">OCR</a> scanners can, in conjunction with text-to-speech software, read the contents of books and documents aloud via computer. Vendors also build closed-circuit televisions that electronically magnify paper, and even change its contrast and color, for visually impaired users. For more information, consult <a href="Assistive%20technology">Assistive technology</a>.
In adults with low vision there is no conclusive evidence supporting one form of reading aid over another. In several studies stand-mounted devices allowed faster reading than hand-held or portable optical aids. While electronic aids may allow faster reading for individuals with low vision, portability, ease of use, and affordability must be considered for people.
Children with low vision sometimes have reading delays, but do benefit from phonics-based beginning reading instruction methods. Engaging phonics instruction is multisensory, highly motivating, and hands-on. Typically students are first taught the most frequent sounds of the alphabet letters, especially the so-called short vowel sounds, then taught to blend sounds together with three-letter consonant-vowel-consonant words such as cat, red, sit, hot, sun. Hands-on (or kinesthetically appealing) VERY enlarged print materials such as those found in "The Big Collection of Phonics Flipbooks" by Lynn Gordon (Scholastic, 2010) are helpful for teaching word families and blending skills to beginning readers with low vision. Beginning reading instructional materials should focus primarily on the lower-case letters, not the capital letters (even though they are larger) because reading text requires familiarity (mostly) with lower-case letters. Phonics-based beginning reading should also be supplemented with phonemic awareness lessons, writing opportunities, and many read-alouds (literature read to children daily) to stimulate motivation, vocabulary development, concept development, and comprehension skill development. Many children with low vision can be successfully included in regular education environments. Parents may need to be vigilant to ensure that the school provides the teacher and students with appropriate low vision resources, for example technology in the classroom, classroom aide time, modified educational materials, and consultation assistance with low vision experts.
Epidemiology.
The <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">WHO</a> estimates that in 2012 there were 285 million visually impaired people in the world, of which 246 million had low vision and 39 million were blind.
Of those who are blind 90% live in the developing world. Worldwide for each blind person, an average of 3.4 people have low vision, with country and regional variation ranging from 2.4 to 5.5.
By age: Visual impairment is unequally distributed across age groups. More than 82% of all people who are blind are 50 years of age and older, although they represent only 19% of the world's population. Due to the expected number of years lived in blindness (blind years), childhood blindness remains a significant problem, with an estimated 1.4 million blind children below age 15.
By gender: Available studies consistently indicate that in every region of the world, and at all ages, females have a significantly higher risk of being visually impaired than males.
By geography: Visual impairment is not distributed uniformly throughout the world. More than 90% of the world's visually impaired live in developing countries.
Since the estimates of the 1990s, new data based on the 2002 global population show a reduction in the number of people who are blind or visually impaired, and those who are blind from the effects of infectious diseases, but an increase in the number of people who are blind from conditions related to longer life spans.
In 1987, it was estimated that 598,000 people in the United States met the legal definition of blindness. Of this number, 58% were over the age of 65. In 1994–1995, 1.3 million Americans reported legal blindness.
Society and culture.
Legal definition.
To determine which people qualify for special assistance because of their visual disabilities, various governments have specific definitions for legal blindness. In <a href="North%20America">North America</a> and most of <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, legal blindness is defined as <a href="visual%20acuity">visual acuity</a> (vision) of 20/200 (6/60) or less in the better eye with best correction possible. This means that a legally blind individual would have to stand from an object to see it—with <a href="corrective%20lens">corrective lens</a>es—with the same degree of clarity as a normally sighted person could from . In many areas, people with average acuity who nonetheless have a <a href="visual%20field">visual field</a> of less than 20 <a href="degree%20%28angle%29">degrees</a> (the norm being 180 degrees) are also classified as being legally blind.
Approximately fifteen percent of those deemed legally blind, by any measure, have no light or form perception. The rest have some vision, from light perception alone to relatively good acuity. <a href="Low%20vision">Low vision</a> is sometimes used to describe visual acuities from 20/70 to 20/200.
Literature and art.
Antiquity.
The <a href="Moche%20%28culture%29">Moche</a> people of ancient <a href="Peru">Peru</a> depicted the blind in their ceramics.
In Greek myth, <a href="Tiresias">Tiresias</a> was a prophet famous for his <a href="clairvoyance">clairvoyance</a>. According to one myth, he was blinded by the gods as punishment for revealing their secrets, while another holds that he was blinded as punishment after he saw <a href="Athena">Athena</a> naked while she was bathing. In <a href="the%20Odyssey">the Odyssey</a>, the one-eyed Cyclops <a href="Polyphemus">Polyphemus</a> captures <a href="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>, who blinds Polyphemus to escape. In Norse mythology, <a href="Loki">Loki</a> tricks the blind god <a href="H%C3%B6%C3%B0r">Höðr</a> into killing his brother <a href="Baldr">Baldr</a>, the god of happiness.
The <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a> contains numerous instances of <a href="Miracles%20of%20Jesus">Jesus performing miracles</a> to heal the blind. According to the Gospels, Jesus healed <a href="Healing%20the%20two%20blind%20men%20in%20Galilee">the two blind men of Galilee</a>, <a href="Blind%20man%20of%20Bethsaida">the blind man of Bethsaida</a>, <a href="Healing%20the%20blind%20near%20Jericho">the blind man of Jericho</a> and <a href="Healing%20the%20blind%20at%20birth">the man who was born blind</a>.
The parable of the <a href="blind%20men%20and%20an%20elephant">blind men and an elephant</a> has crossed between many religious traditions and is part of <a href="Jainism">Jain</a>, <a href="Buddhist">Buddhist</a>, <a href="Sufi">Sufi</a> and <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a> lore. In various versions of the tale, a group of blind men (or men in the dark) touch an <a href="elephant">elephant</a> to learn what it is like. Each one feels a different part, but only one part, such as the side or the tusk. They then compare notes and learn that they are in complete disagreement.
"<a href="Three%20Blind%20Mice">Three Blind Mice</a>" is a medieval <a href="English%20language">English</a> <a href="nursery%20rhyme">nursery rhyme</a> about three blind mice whose tails are cut off after chasing the farmer's wife. The work is explicitly incongruous, ending with the comment "Did you ever see such a sight in your life, As three blind mice?"
Modern times.
Poet <a href="John%20Milton">John Milton</a>, who went blind in mid-life, composed "<a href="On%20His%20Blindness">On His Blindness</a>", a sonnet about coping with blindness. The work posits that "[those] who best Bear [God]'s mild yoke, they serve him best."
The Dutch painter and engraver <a href="Rembrandt">Rembrandt</a> often depicted scenes from the apocryphal <a href="Book%20of%20Tobit">Book of Tobit</a>, which tells the story of a blind patriarch who is healed by his son, Tobias, with the help of the archangel <a href="Raphael%20%28archangel%29">Raphael</a>.
Slaver-turned-abolitionist <a href="John%20Newton">John Newton</a> composed the hymn "<a href="Amazing%20Grace">Amazing Grace</a>" about a wretch who "once was lost, but now am found, Was blind, but now I see." Blindness, in this sense, is used both metaphorically (to refer to someone who was ignorant but later became knowledgeable) and literally, as a reference to those healed in the Bible. In the later years of his life, Newton himself would go blind.
<a href="H.%20G.%20Wells">H. G. Wells</a>' story "<a href="The%20Country%20of%20the%20Blind">The Country of the Blind</a>" explores what would happen if a sighted man found himself trapped in a country of blind people to emphasise society's attitude to blind people by turning the situation on its head.
<a href="Bob%20Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>'s anti-war song "<a href="Blowin%27%20in%20the%20Wind">Blowin' in the Wind</a>" twice alludes to metaphorical blindness: "How many times can a man turn his head // and pretend that he just doesn't see... How many times must a man look up // Before he can see the sky?"
Contemporary fiction contains numerous well-known . Some of these characters can see by means of devices, such as the <a href="Marvel%20Comics">Marvel Comics</a> superhero <a href="Daredevil%20%28Marvel%20Comics%20character%29">Daredevil</a>, who can see via his super-human hearing acuity, or "<a href="Star%20Trek">Star Trek</a>"'s <a href="Geordi%20La%20Forge">Geordi La Forge</a>, who can see with the aid of a <a href="VISOR">VISOR</a>, a fictional device that transmits optical signals to his brain.
Sports.
Blind and partially sighted people participate in sports, such as <a href="Swimming%20%28sport%29">swimming</a>, <a href="snow%20skiing">snow skiing</a> and <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a>. Some sports have been invented or adapted for the blind, such as <a href="goalball">goalball</a>, <a href="Paralympic%20association%20football">association football</a>, <a href="blind%20cricket">cricket</a>, <a href="blind%20golf">golf</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="bowling">bowling</a>, and <a href="beep%20baseball">beep baseball</a>. The worldwide authority on sports for the blind is the <a href="International%20Blind%20Sports%20Federation">International Blind Sports Federation</a>. People with vision impairments have participated in the <a href="Paralympic%20Games">Paralympic Games</a> since the <a href="1976%20Summer%20Paralympics">1976 Toronto summer Paralympics</a>.
Metaphorical uses.
The word "blind" (adjective and verb) is often used to signify a lack of knowledge of something. For example, a blind date is a date in which the people involved have not previously met; a <a href="blind%20experiment">blind experiment</a> is one in which information is kept from either the experimenter or the participant to mitigate the <a href="placebo%20effect">placebo effect</a> or <a href="observer%20bias">observer bias</a>. The expression "<a href="blind%20leading%20the%20blind">blind leading the blind</a>" refers to incapable people leading other incapable people. Being blind to something means not understanding or being aware of it. A "<a href="blind%20spot%20%28vision%29">blind spot</a>" is an area where someone cannot see: for example, where a car driver cannot see because parts of his car's bodywork are in the way; metaphorically, a topic on which an individual is unaware of their own biases, and therefore of the resulting distortions of their own judgements (see <a href="Bias%20blind%20spot">Bias blind spot</a>).
Research.
A 2008 study tested the effect of using <a href="gene%20therapy">gene therapy</a> to help restore the sight of patients with a rare form of inherited blindness, known as <a href="Leber%27s%20congenital%20amaurosis">Leber's congenital amaurosis</a> or LCA. Leber's Congenital Amaurosis damages the light receptors in the retina and usually begins affecting sight in early childhood, with worsening vision until complete blindness around the age of 30. The study used a common cold virus to deliver a normal version of the gene called <a href="RPE65">RPE65</a> directly into the eyes of affected patients. All three patients, aged 19, 22 and 25, responded well to the treatment and reported improved vision following the procedure.
Two experimental treatments for retinal problems include a cybernetic replacement and transplant of fetal retinal cells.
There is no high-quality evidence on the effect of assistive technologies on educational outcomes and quality of life in children with low vision as of 2015, nor is there evidence on magnifying reading aids in children. Low-vision rehabilitation does not appear to have an important impact on health-related quality of life, though some low-vision rehabilitation interventions, particularly psychological therapies and methods of enhancing vision, may improve vision-related quality of life in people with sight loss.
Other animals.
Statements that certain species of <a href="mammal">mammal</a>s are "born blind" refers to them being born with their eyes closed and their eyelids fused together; the eyes open later. One example is the <a href="rabbit">rabbit</a>. In humans, the eyelids are fused for a while before birth, but open again before the normal birth time; however, very <a href="premature%20babies">premature babies</a> are sometimes born with their eyes fused shut, and opening later. Other animals, such as the <a href="blind%20mole%20rat">blind mole rat</a>, are truly blind and rely on other senses.
The theme of blind animals has been a powerful one in literature. <a href="Peter%20Shaffer">Peter Shaffer</a>'s Tony Award-winning play, <a href="Equus%20%28play%29">"Equus"</a>, tells the story of a boy who blinds six horses. <a href="Theodore%20Taylor%20%28author%29">Theodore Taylor</a>'s classic young adult novel, "<a href="The%20Trouble%20With%20Tuck">The Trouble With Tuck</a>", is about a teenage girl, Helen, who trains her blind dog to follow and trust a seeing-eye dog.
